title: Native Gap Conservation Reserve
text:
Native Gap Conservation Reserve is a <a href="protected%20area">protected area</a> in the <a href="Northern%20Territory%20of%20Australia">Northern Territory of Australia</a>.
It is located approximately north of <a href="Alice%20Springs%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Alice Springs</a> and south of <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a>. The park is found just off along the <a href="Stuart%20Highway">Stuart Highway</a> on the western side, via an unsealed track to a telecommunications tower in the nearby <a href="Hann%20Range">Hann Range</a>.
The <a href="traditional%20owners">traditional owners</a> of the area are the <a href="Aranda%20people">Arrente</a> and Anmatyerr peoples to whom it is a <a href="sacred%20site">sacred site</a>. The area is at the junction of many <a href="dreamtime">creation stories</a>, and the name of the site in the Arrente dialect is "Arurlte Artwatye", where "Arurlte" means 'the top of the shoulders across the neck' and "Artwatye" means 'gap'.
The name of the site is derived from the <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> ridge that dominates the reserve standing above the surrounding Burt Plain.
The name of the area was first used in 1872 when one of the builders of the <a href="Overland%20telegraph">Overland telegraph</a>, W. W. Mills, reported to <a href="Charles%20Todd%20%28pioneer%29">Charles Todd</a> that they had come to a "Native Gap". He wrote of a "native well" that was situated in a gap in Hann's Range. The gap is thought to have taken the name of the well it contained.
In 1880 workers on the telegraph widened the gap by blasting the rock with explosives but in doing so destroying the water-holding rocks.
Flora found at the reserve include the <a href="Ficus%20brachypoda">native fig</a>, <a href="Callitris%20glaucophylla">white cypress pine</a> found up on the ridge along with shrubs including "<a href="Acacia%20monticola">Acacia monticola</a>" and "<a href="Acacia%20melleodora">Acacia melleodora</a>", "<a href="Eucalyptus%20gamophylla">Eucalyptus gamophylla</a>", and "<a href="Eucalyptus%20sessilis">Eucalyptus sessilis</a>" also grow on top of the ridge even in the most exposed areas. <a href="Acacia%20estrophiolata">ironwood</a>, <a href="Corymbia%20opaca">desert bloodwood</a> and <a href="Corymbia%20aparrerinja">ghost gums</a> on the sandy flats. Desert grasses and <a href="Triodia%20%28grass%29">spinifex</a> are found throughout the reserve, with <a href="Drosera">Drosera</a> growing on the flats after rain. Other plants found through the reserve include <a href="Grevillea%20wickhamii">Grevillea wickhamii</a> and some <a href="Gossypium">Gossypium</a> species
Birdlife found on the reserve include <a href="western%20bowerbird">western bowerbird</a>s that feed on the native fig, <a href="little%20woodswallow">little woodswallow</a>s, <a href="dusky%20grasswren">dusky grasswren</a>s among the spinifex and <a href="brown%20quail">brown quail</a> after wet seasons. Other species found include <a href="whistling%20kite">whistling kite</a>, <a href="rainbow%20bee-eater">rainbow bee-eater</a>, <a href="willie%20wagtail">willie wagtail</a>, <a href="inland%20thornbill">inland thornbill</a>, <a href="variegated%20fairywren">variegated fairywren</a>, <a href="mistletoebird">mistletoebird</a>, <a href="grey-headed%20honeyeater">grey-headed honeyeater</a> and <a href="Torresian%20crow">Torresian crow</a>.
Other fauna found on the reserve include the <a href="Tachyglossus%20aculeatus">short-beaked echidna</a>, <a href="Macropus%20robustus">euro</a> and the <a href="Petrogale%20lateralis">black-footed rock-wallaby</a>.
See also.
<a href="Protected%20areas%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Protected areas of the Northern Territory</a>
